Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Dynamic Light Scattering Test of Bond Model Predictions for the Dynamics of Network-forming Liquids near the Glass Transition
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Abstract

The amorphous solid phase is, in principle, endemic to all liquids despite a propensity for some liquids to crystallize when cooled. However, the manner in which a liquid thickens in advance of solidification is vastly different among different materials. Past research has demonstrated a clear link between the dynamics of a supercooled, glass-forming liquid and its chemical structure and thermodynamic properties referred to as "fragility". In this project, dynamic light scattering, Raman spectroscopy and differential scanning calorimetry are being applied to probe how liquid dynamics are directly affected by simple structural changes created in network-forming systems. The results will form a precise test of a proposed thermodynamic model (Bond Model) presently available. Work will be carried out both by graduate (MS) and undergraduate students providing hands-on research experience to augment their science education.


Non-technical Abstract

Technology thrives on exploiting the novel properties of materials. Among these, glassy materials possess unique mechanical, optical and electrical properties of importance for many state-of-the-art devices. However, for their potential to be realized, glassy materials must be solidified from the liquid state without crystallization occurring. This then requires an understanding of the liquid-to-glass transition and in particular an understanding of how chemical structure of the liquid affects the thickening process itself. In this project, visible light scattered by a glass-forming liquid is used to monitor this thickening process on a microscopic level. A series of glass-forming liquids are to be investigated in which the chemical structure can be systematically altered by either increasing or decreasing the average number of chemical bonds present in the liquid. With each modification of the structure, the corresponding changes in dynamical properties of the liquid will be assessed to test predictions of a simple model based upon the average number of bonds present. Graduate (MS) and undergraduate students will conduct this research as means of training the next generation of professional scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The glass transition is a peculiar change in the state of matter in which a flowing liquid gradually solidifies as it is cooled.  Anyone that has watched an artisan glassblower working can attest to the rather delicate balance between flow and solidity that must be maintained to work a glass object into a desired shape.  Moreover, this delicate balance is integral to larger scale manufacturing of glass products and is one of the reasons for efforts to be able to predict the properties of the glassy melt based on details of its chemistry and atomic bond structure alone.  Two parameters characterize the dynamics of molten glass.  The first is the glass transition temperature, Tg, that marks a level of thermal energy needed for solidity to be overcome.  This temperature can be raised or lowered by altering the chemistry of the glass.  The other is the "fragility", m, that characterizes how sensitive the melt is to changes in temperature above Tg.  Glasses with a high fragility are very sensitive to small temperature changes and so are challenging to process while glasses with a low fragility (m ≈ 20) are more easy to manipulate.

Although a glass can in principle be formed from any liquid, even water, most of the commercially-relevant glasses are network-forming materials whose atoms are connected together by discrete bonds to form a sort of "balls-and-sticks" structure in which each atom (ball) can have multiple bonds (sticks) connecting it to other atoms (Fig. 1).  Chemistry can be used to either increase or decrease the density of these bonds between atoms with corresponding changes in the fragility of the melt.  In our light scattering studies of sodium phosphate glasses, we observed the fragility to increase as sodium was added due to its tendency to reduce the connectedness of the network (Fig. 2).  Interestingly, our trend matched a previous result for, non-oxide, chalcogenide network-forming glasses only with a surprising twist: the connectivity of the phosphates only matched if we viewed its network as constructed of tetrahedral "balls" linked together by bridging oxygen "sticks" instead of interconnected atoms (Fig. 3) .  This amounts to a coarse-graining of the network in the oxides that emphasizes the weaker connections between more "rigid structural units" (i.e., the tetrahedra). 

It was odd then that the fragility of alkali borate glasses would increase (see Fig. 4) since the addition of alkali ions increases the connectivity of the oxide network.  This puzzle was resolved only by recognizing that the borate network is composed of much larger rigid structural units - ring like structures that contain multiple tetrahedra into one solid unit - which require a higher level of coarse-graining.  When properly accounted for, we found that the fragility of the borate (and also germanate and chalcogenides) all follow a common, universal dependence on the network connectivity alone (see Fig. 5), regardless of chemical differences!  The signifcance of this finding is that the dynamics (i.e., the fragility and sensitivity of the melt to temperature changes) can be understood solely by understanding the bond network structures of these commercially-relevant glasses.

Broader Impacts

Creighton University is a small, liberal arts institution that has an impressive track record for involving undergraduate students in cutting-edge research.  Over one-third of undergraduates participate in research while at Creighton and deliver more than 200 research-based presentations each year at local and national conference settings.  Our research project mentored 7 undergraduate and 6 graduate students (2 year Masters of Science) during its run - contributing to the development and training of the next generation of professional scientists.  Moreover, through collaborations with one National Lab (Sandia), students benefitted from an exposure to different research cultures including both pure science and engineering.

As for our key research finding, the improved understanding about what controls the flow of a glassy melt near the glass transition in terms of just structural properties, could have a lasting impact on the process of glass manufacturing and implications for glass formation in other fields.   The formation of glass arises in many instances in nature: in astronomy, the water on comets is predominantly in a frozen, non-crystalline form; in biology, sugar solutions secreted into the cells of certain living creatures solidify in winter without crystallization to allow the cells to thaw in spring without damage.  The transition from liquid to solid is ubiquitous and will continue to intrigue humankind for years yet to come.
